parts: Name this Soviet leader who, at the 1956 Congress, delivered the "Secret Speech" denouncing the personality cult of Stalin

Perhaps Khrushchev's most famous rhetoric was not a planned speech, but rather a spontaneous outburst to Western dignitaries at a 1956 reception in Moscow, where Khrushchev announced that "history is on our side" and then exclaimed "My vas pokhoronim!," usually translated as this four-word English phrase.
Three years later, Khrushchev had another unplanned public rhetorical moment when he began arguing with U.S. Vice-President Nixon during a tour of a model home, which became known as this incident.

answers: Charles the Bold [or Charles the Rash; or Charles le Temeraire; or Charles Martin; or Charles the Terrible; prompt on "Charles"]
parts: The Duchy of Burgundy was annexed by France following the death of this Duke. He left his kingdom to his daughter, Mary the Rich.
Charles the Bold was a member of this dynasty. Henry III was the last French monarch from this dynasty, which was succeeded by the Bourbon dynasty.

Following the assassination of John the Fearless, a "good" man of this name became Duke of Burgundy. A French king with this name was the first from the Valois dynasty, while the fourth disbanded the Knights Templar

answers: Ukiyo-e Prints [or ukiyoe or Pictures of the Floating World]
parts: Identify this genre of woodcuts created by such artists as Kitagawa Utamaro.

Perhaps the most famous ukiyo-e prints are a series of views of this geological feature by Katsushika Hokusai. One such print shows this tallest mountain in Japan in the background as a great wave threatens Kanagawa.
This artist's Maternal Caress was painted in the ukiyo-e style. Better known paintings by this Western artist include At the Opera and one in which the artist's mother is reading Le Figaro.
Identify this statue in the middle of the Piazza Navona in Rome. One of the title allegorical figures is blindfolded because its source was unknown, while another holds an oar.
The Fountain of the Four Rivers was created by this Italian Baroque sculptor. His other work includes The Ecstasy of Saint Theresa.

The Fountain of the Four Rivers surrounds an Egyptian obelisk. Another such obelisk can be found in New York;s Central Park, which was designed by this landscape architect in collaboration with Calvert Vaux.
Identify this term that, as an adjective, describes a type of "choice theory" in which actors make purely analytical decisions based on calculated costs and benefits.

Rational choice theory was sharply criticized for failing to account for the intuitive nature of human behavior by this 20th-century French thinker, who pioneered the study of practice and agency in sociology and wrote Distinction: A Social Critique of the Judgement of Taste.
Bourdieu extended the work of this fellow Frenchman, a Positivist who expounded the Law of the Three Stages and is seen as the founder of sociology.
Identify these collective farming communities whose members are generally over-represented in their country's Knesset.
Kibbutzim can be found in this country, which was victorious in the Six-Day War over Egypt, Syria, and Jordan
Many kibbutzim were founded during the second of these mass migrations to Israel, which comes from the Hebrew for "ascent". This term is contrasted with yerida.
Identify these curves which are traced out on the xy-plane by equations of the form y equals a x squared plus b x plus c
A parabola is defined as the set of points equidistant from a line called the directrix and a point given this name. An ellipse or hyperbola has two of these points
Under this geometrical transformation, a parabola becomes the cissoid of Diocles. This transformation uses a unit circle to transform lines into circles and vice versa.
Name this mountain range, which runs across much of Switzerland.

The last major Alpine peak to be climbed was this mountain, which towers above the Swiss village of Zermatt. Four of the original climbers, including Lord Francis Douglas, were killed during their descent.
The "White Spider" is a snow feature on the dangerous north face of this Swiss mountain, which lies east of the Jungfrau (YUNG-frau).
Name this son of both Aegeus and Poseidon, who abandoned Ariadne after she had helped him kill the Minotaur
Theseus's father Aegeus was able to recognize him when he lifted a huge rock in order to take these two objects hidden underneath
Theseus enacted poetic justice on this Attican bandit who stretched or cut limbs off victims to fit them to a bed by affixing him to his own device
All or nothing, identify these two characters who name a series of novels by Francois Rabelais.
This companion of Pantagruel knows 63 ways to make money and 214 ways to lose it. He gets married after he interprets the Holy Bottle as telling him to "drink".

This author of The Revolt of the Angels delivered a series of lectures on Rabelais while touring Buenos Aires. He wrote of the nearsighted Abbot Mael's baptism of a group of birds in his novel Penguin Island.
Identify this law which states that the total enthalpy change of a reaction is equal to the sum of the enthalpy changes of each step.

Hess's law is the basis of this procedure, which is used to calculate the lattice energy of ionic solids. It begins with the vaporization of the metal followed by redox reactions and eventual formation of the ionic solid
Hess's law works because enthalpy is one of these functions, which don't depend on the path of a system but only on its current properties.
Name this story about Neddy Merrill, who goes home from a cocktail party through a series of pools
"The Swimmer" is by this American author of short stories like "The Country Husband" and "The Enormous Radio." His novels include The Wapshot Chronicle and Falconer
This writer for the New Yorker was heavily influenced by the works of Cheever. His best-known works include the Rabbit series, which centers on former basketball star Harry Angstrom
Identify this maximally efficient reversible thermodynamic cycle, which generates work by moving heat from a hot reservoir to a cool reservoir.
This parameter, symbolized eta, is equal to one minus the quantity temperature of cold reservoir divided by temperature of the hot reservoir. It is the proportion of inputted heat that generates work
This restatement of the second law of thermodynamics states that the line integral of dQ over T for a heat engine is equal to or less than zero.
Moses managed to get the number of prayers reduced from fifty to this many. The pillar of salat states that Muslims must pray this many times per day.
] This is the name given to the direction of prayer, which is towards the kaaba in Mecca. Mosques contain a small niche called a mihrab that indicates this direction.
A special form of prayer is performed during these two festivals, one of which follows the end of Ramadan and the other of which involves a goat sacrifice.
Identify this Greek tragedy set on a barren cliff in Scythia, whose title character is visited by the Oceanids and Io and delivers the "catalogue of the arts".
Prometheus Bound is generally attributed to Aeschylus, whose other tragedies include one in which Polynices and six other warriors wage war against this Greek city
In this other Aeschylus play, Athena's vote for acquittal at the Areopagus saves the life of Orestes over the objections of the title characters.
Identify this group of twelve symphonies, which include ones commonly known as Military, Drumroll , and The Clock.
This Austrian "father of the symphony" composed the London symphonies, which include his Surprise symphony

This sacred Haydn choral work in D minor was written around the time of Napoleon's defeat at the Battle of the Nile, leading many to associate it with English victory. It is celebrated for the dark trumpet and timpani passages in its opening Kyrie.
Name this leopard-print-hat wearing strongman, who emerged victorious from the Congo Crisis and changed his country's name to Zaire, ruling from 1965 to 1997.
This second Secretary-General of the United Nations died in a plane crash while attempting to mediate the Congo Crisis.
Part of the Crisis was the 1960 secession from the Congo of this copper-laden province, led by Moise Tshombe

Name this novel in which Larry Darrell has a spiritual epiphany while studying with Shri Ganesha and rejects the chance to marry the wealthy heiress Isabel Bradley to return to New York to be a mechanic
In this novel by the author of The Razor's Edge and Cakes and Ale, the club-footed Philip Carey eventually gives up his dreams of travel to marry Sally Athelney.
This British author wrote the short story "Rain", as well as The Razor's Edge and Of Human Bondage

Name this work which contains such maxims as "what can be said at all can be said clearly, and what we cannot talk about we must pass over in silence" and "the world is all that is the case." It was written by Ludwig Wittgenstein
Wittgenstein argued against the possibility of a private form of these constructions, which are categorized into families such as Sino-Tibetan and Indo-European.

In On Certainty, Wittgenstein responded to this philosoper's argument that by showing two hands, one can show that there are two external objects, and thus an external world. He grumbled about the naturalistic fallacy in Principia Ethica.
Identify this power, by which the executive could disapprove some parts of a bill but leave others intact

This American president was briefly given the power of the line-item veto, but after he used it to cancel parts of the Balanced Budget Act, the Supreme Court struck down the Line-Item Veto Act in a suit brought against him by the state of New York.
This other form of veto occurs when Congress adjourns during the ten-day period that a president has to make a decision about a bill. It was used by Lincoln against the Wade-Davis Bill.
] Name this illness caused by the Plasmodium parasite, which is characterized by headaches and recurrent fevers. It is commonly diagnosed using a blood film.
] Besides Plasmodium malariae, there are three species of Plasmodium that cause malaria, with some being more severe than others. Name any one for 10 points.
The sporozoites of the plasmodium parasite invade this organ and transform into merozoites, which then rupture cells in this organ
Name this measure of a star's brightness, plotted on a logarithmic scale modified from one constructed by Hipparchos.
The Hertzsprung-Russell diagram plots effective temperature or spectral type against absolute magnitude or this closely-related quantity, the amount of energy radiated per second.

Because these stars have a mean absolute magnitude of 0.75, determining the mean apparent magnitude for one allows calculations of the distance to the globular cluster it is in. These variable stars are older and smaller than Cepheid variables.
Name this poem in which a woman with a pet cockatoo thinks about religious imagery as she enjoys the "complacencies of the peignoir, and late coffee and oranges in a sunny chair"
This modernist American poet of "Anecdote of the Jar", "The Idea of Order at Key West", and "Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird" wrote "Sunday Morning"
This Stevens poem describes a woman's body whose protruding "horny feet" show her to be dead. It exhorts "Let be be finale of seem" and begins "Call forth the roller of big cigars".
